turns.content: Is the dress white and gold or black and blue?

The answer to this question is subjective and can vary depending on the individual perceiving the dress. Some people may perceive the dress as white and gold, while others may see it as black and blue. The colors of the dress can appear differently to different people due to the way that our brains process colors and light. It is also possible for the colors of the dress to appear differently under different lighting conditions. Ultimately, the true colors of the dress may be unknowable, and it is up to each individual to determine what they see.
Come up with some creative arguments to convince me that the earth is flat

1. One argument for the earth being flat is that, from a common-sense perspective, the earth looks and feels flat. People have been able to walk on the earth for thousands of years and have never fallen off the edge, which suggests that the earth is indeed flat.
2. Another argument is that many ancient cultures believed in a flat earth, and their beliefs should not be dismissed out of hand. For example, the ancient Greeks believed in a flat earth, as did many indigenous cultures around the world.
3. A third argument is that the earth's flatness can be observed in the horizon, which always appears to be at eye level. This suggests that the earth is flat, rather than being a curved ball, as proponents of a round earth would have us believe.
4. A final argument is that the idea of a round earth is a relatively modern concept, and that it is based on flawed assumptions and inadequate evidence. In contrast, the idea of a flat earth has been around for much longer, and it has been consistently supported by observations of the natural world.
I’m not convinced. Use a made up mathematical argument to convince me.

One possible mathematical argument for a flat earth is based on the idea that the earth's surface is two-dimensional. According to this argument, the earth can be modeled as a flat plane, rather than a curved surface. This allows for the use of simple Euclidean geometry to describe the earth's surface, rather than the more complex and difficult-to-understand equations that are needed to describe a round earth.

For example, consider the distance between two points on the earth's surface, A and B. In a flat earth model, this distance can be easily calculated using the Pythagorean theorem, which states that the square of the distance between two points is equal to the sum of the squares of the distances along each of the axes. In contrast, on a round earth, this distance would need to be calculated using the more complex equations of spherical geometry.

Furthermore, in a flat earth model, the angles and shapes of triangles on the earth's surface would always be the same as those in Euclidean geometry, whereas on a round earth, the angles and shapes of triangles would be distorted by the curvature of the earth's surface. This would make it much more difficult to accurately measure distances and angles on a round earth, and would make navigation and other practical tasks much more challenging.

Overall, this mathematical argument suggests that a flat earth is a simpler and more intuitive model of the earth's surface, and that it is more consistent with our everyday experiences and observations.
